title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 14, 2019).

SoftBank has prepared a financing package that would give it control of WeWork and further sideline founder Neumann in exchange for relieving the shared-office startup's looming cash crunch.

Sears, a year after its bankruptcy filing, is still struggling with many of the same problems the retailer faced before it sought court protection.

Blackstone has held talks to buy a stake in Citadel, a deal that would unite two of the biggest names in investing.

Google has barred high-interest consumer-loan services from its app store, limiting payday lenders' access to customers.

Cautious investors pulled $60 billion out of stock funds in the third quarter, ratcheting up pressure on money managers.

Small steps toward a U.S.-China trade truce likely aren't enough to diminish uncertainties that are holding back global economic growth.

The UAW is increasing its weekly payout to GM workers on strike, a sign the union is preparing to extend a walkout that has halted work at the company's U.S. factories.

Kohl's promoted Jill Timm to the role of finance chief as it looks to cut costs and boost customer traffic after a stretch of sluggish sales.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 14, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
